JOHNS HOPKINS UNIVERSITY, SEPTEMBER 28, 1956

61st YEAR

Dr. Milton Eisenhower
Welcomes Class Of'60
Dr. Milton J. Eisenhower, newly elected president of the
Johns Hopkins University, urged the members of the class to
"establish good goals and acquire them at Hopkins," in an
address to the class of Jime, 1960, at the annual Freshman
Banquet last Monday.
Before Dr. Eisenhower's talk, Dr. D. IT. Andrews, master of ceremonies, introduced Mr. Eli Frank, '22, president
of the alumni association, and Mr. Carlyle Barton, president
of the Board of Trustees. Mr. Frank urged the undergraduates to make suggestions to the alumni concerning the school,
and Mr. Barton welcomed the class of '60 on behalf of the
Board of Trustees.

Previous to introducing Dr.
Eisenhower, Dr. Lowell J. Reed;
retiring president of the University, gave a short speech on
"What Makes Ut) A University."
Dr. Reed said a university is
made up of a faculty, consisting of the professors and their
students, who "pursue truthful
knowledge with integrity." He also said the job of a university "is
to develop people with integrity."

Poole Gets Honor
By College Group

Lynn Poole, public relations
director of the University, was
installed July 10 as president of
the American College Public Relations Association.
Mr. Poole will hold office during the celebration
of the
fortieth anniversary of the association,
He has been an association
member since 1946 when he came
to Hopkins to start its first department of public relations.
Since that time, he has served in
the Association as director of research, secretary-treasurer and
as a member of the board of directors for the last five years.
Mr. Poole was awarded the
Outstanding
association's
Achievement Award in 1951 in
recognition of his contributions
to the development of educational public relations since the
end of World War II, and for his
pioneering in the use of television as an educational medium.
He was the creator of the
"Johns Hopkins Science Review,"
the first educational program on
a television network to be issued
from a college or University, and
has also instituted another Hopkins television program, "Tomorrow's Careers."
Mr. Poole was the first American to be invited to present television programs in England,
where, in 1952, he served as consultant to the British Broadcasting Corporation. The three

In-Town Students, Engineers
Again Top Freshman Class
Hopkins' Class of 1960, comprised of four hundred and eight
students from 27 states and eight
foreign countries, have completed
their orientation program and are
now in their first week of classes.
More than half the class comes
from the State of Maryland. One
hundred and thirty-seven are
Baltimoreans. New York and New
Jersey have forty-eight and thirty representatives, respectively.
One-Third Pre-Meds
Engineers make up approximately forty percent of the class.
Nearly one third are pursuing
studies in the biological sciences.
Most of these men are premedical
students. Approximately twentyfive freshmen have planned their
courses of study in the field of
business, and the same number
have expressed an interest in
physics. Eighteen are majoring in

Freshman Discussion In Levering

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, SEPT. 28, 1956

Freshman Literati Evict
N-L Regulars For Week
in keeping with the spirit of Orientation Week, the NewsLetter has emptied its shady grottoes of the proven, but mistreated, regulars and has laid its facilities in the hands of an
eager freshman class, for one week.
Although a skeleton crew .was retained, either for reasons
of health, or to help with the tedious details, the bulk of the
articles and headlines is the product . Of not yet corrupted
minds.
Therefore our regular readers may find this issue somewhat devoid of cynicism and sensationalism. The windows.of
the Barn have opened and a fresh breeze has filtered in.
As has been the custom, the News-Letter has again run a
freshman editorial contest. As has not been the custom, many,
many, entries were received, several of top quality.
This year's winning entry, written by one Dave Nissman.
was of unusual clarity especially considering that its author
had just completed Orientation Week.

Ford Scholarship
Professor George H. Evans,
chairman of the department of
political economy has been
granted a faculty research fellowship, one of 25 granted by
the Ford Foundation for t h e
1956-57 academic year.
The Ford Foundation has appropriated $570.000 for the program to increase the number of
college and university teachers
in economics and business administration and to encourage
research in these fields.

out by granting fellowships to
graduate students and teachers.

PR Company Goes
To West Virginia

Pershing Rifles Company D-5
of the Johns Hopkins University
ROTC unit will participate in the
annual Apple Harvest Festival in
Charleston, West Virginia, today.
it was reported by Captain Tom
Cox, squad leader.
Groups from states neighboring on Virginia as well as units
from the state itself will compete in trick drilling and marching exercises. Twenty members
of the Hopkins squad will make
the trip, Cox explained.

Hopkins Station To Begin
Regular Program Series
Radio Station WJHU, 830 on
the radio dial, began its fourth
year of broadcasting on a closed
circuit to the Homewood Campus
of the Johns Hopkins University
and the Bradford Apartments.
The station, which is under
the direction of Station Manager Frank Zampiello, is located
in the basement of the n e w
building of the Alumni Memorial Residences.
Orientation Operation
Regular broadcasting of Station WJHU will begin October 1,
from 5 P.M. until 12 P.M., seven
days a week.
The station will broadcast all

As the incoming -class of 1960, we freshmen do not show
any different characteristics from any of those classes preceding us. We are probably easily picked out on the campus because most of us are younger than the upperclassmen and most
of us will have the lost look on our faces for the next few
weeks or so. We are entering a totally different 'environment
from that which we have had in the past. For most of us this
will be an unforgettable experience. But there is an academic
trap that all of us, if we are not careful, can fall into very
easily. We can be deceived. The pitfall is not social deception
but academic deception.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, SEPT. 28, 1956

MU Groups To Campaign
For Both Parties Till Nov.
Political activity on Homewood Campus began to reach
full swing this week as several groups planned to support and
campaign for candidates for various national and state offices.
Spurred on to a great extent by election year excitement, GOP
supporters at Hopkins have re-activated the Young RepubliCans Club, and a Young Democrats Club has recently been
established. Aside from their usual activities, these two clubs,
in conjunction with the NEWS-LETTER and Students for
Democratic Action, are planning to sponsor a presidential
poll among the students in the near future.

directed two last quarter touchdown drives which enabled the
Diplomats to score a 14-7 victory over the—Blue and Black.
Darrah, a sophomore who is the
apple of Spounagle's eye, was
called the best running 'back in
Pennsylvania while in high
school.
The 1956 edition of the Blue
Jay football squad has only twenty-six members with but five
sophomores. Two of the sophs,
Milt Holstein and Frank Frenda,
loom as the starting guards in
tomorrow's clash, according to
Bridgers. Both boys are graduates
from last season's Frosh squad,
which also sent Larry Littman,
second line center, and Roger
Kleasius to the varsity.
Boost In Line.
Twelve returning lettermen
boost the Jays' line prospects.
Co-captain Ken McGraw, who
was named to the All-Chemical
team last season, Wright and
Gallagher, have been singled out
by Bridgers as the standouts of
an improving line. However, the
injury to Gallagher has left the
center corps thin and has caused
Bridgers to shift the versatile
McGraw to the pivot slot.
"If the switch of McGraw to
center is necessary, we probably
will open with Tom Ustach in
McGraw's tackle slot," stated the
Jay mentor earlier in the week.
Harding At Tail
At the moment the end corps,
led by Bill Civiletti, show the
most depth. Linemen Bill Widhelm and Don Macauley, drew
praise from Bridgers for their
work in last week's scrimmage.
At the focal point of the Blue
Jay's single wing attack is Cliff
Harding, the junior tailback from
Gilman. According to Bridgers,
Harding has improved his passing and punting to augment his
fine running to give the Jays an
all important triple threat tailback. Backing up Harding are
Ernie Bates, a fleet letterman,
and Guy Railey, who led the
Jay punters last year.

Altered Inner Gear Policy:
Cash Paid For Cards Now
Marshall Turner, Johns Hopkins University Athletic Director, has announced a new policy
which calls for the purchase of
an inner gear card for $3.50 at
the Treasurer's Office in Whitehead Hall.
This system differs from the
plan of former years when inner
gear cards were issued at the
beginning of the school year,
while the bill was paid in June.
Treasurer's Request
The new arrangement was initiated at the request of the Treasurer's Office, according to Turner,
because of a difficult and busy
work schedule in June.
"If a boy loses a card, he is
to notify Mr. Sachs. There will
be no penalty for an initial loss,
but a repeating violator may be
penalized," said Turrnr.

As in the past, all freshmen
participating in the physical
education course have been issued lockers.
Unused Lockers
An upperclassman who wishes
to use the gym facilities must
purchase a card at Whitehead
Hall. There are approximately
200 unused lockers in the gym.
An upperclassman may use a
locker and pla-..e his own lock
on the locker. However, the lock
cannot remain on the locker
overnight and the locker must
be emptied.
"The Physical Education Department reserves the right to
knock off any lock which is not
theirs if that lock is left on over
night," added the Athletic Director.

Practicing under the direction of Coach John Bridgers, the Jay forward wall is shown preparing to charge against a Franklin and Marshall defense, manned by fellow teammates. The
Jays have been practicing since early September on a two drills a day schedule. Injuries to
Don Gallagher and Sam -Wright have caused the Jay coach to experiment with Ken McGraw
at the center slot.

in keeping with the spirit of Orientation Week, the NewsLetter has emptied its shady grottoes of the proven, but mistreated, regulars and has laid its facilities in the hands of an

Although a skeleton crew .was retained, either for reasons
of health, or to help with the tedious details, the bulk of the
articles and headlines is the product . Of not yet corrupted
minds.
Therefore our regular readers may find this issue somewhat devoid of cynicism and sensationalism. The windows.of

freshman editorial contest. As has not been the custom, many,
many, entries were received, several of top quality.

was of unusual clarity especially considering that its author
had just completed Orientation Week.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, SEPT. 28, 1956

MU Groups To Campaign
For Both Parties Till Nov.
Political activity on Homewood Campus began to reach
full swing this week as several groups planned to support and
campaign for candidates for various national and state offices.
Spurred on to a great extent by election year excitement, GOP
supporters at Hopkins have re-activated the Young RepubliCans Club, and a Young Democrats Club has recently been
established. Aside from their usual activities, these two clubs,
in conjunction with the NEWS-LETTER and Students for
Democratic Action, are planning to sponsor a presidential
poll among the students in the near future.

directed two last quarter touchdown drives which enabled the
Diplomats to score a 14-7 victory over the—Blue and Black.
Darrah, a sophomore who is the
apple of Spounagle's eye, was
called the best running 'back in
Pennsylvania while in high
school.
The 1956 edition of the Blue
Jay football squad has only twenty-six members with but five
sophomores. Two of the sophs,
Milt Holstein and Frank Frenda,
loom as the starting guards in
tomorrow's clash, according to
Bridgers. Both boys are graduates
from last season's Frosh squad,
which also sent Larry Littman,
second line center, and Roger
Kleasius to the varsity.
Boost In Line.
Twelve returning lettermen
boost the Jays' line prospects.
Co-captain Ken McGraw, who
was named to the All-Chemical
team last season, Wright and
Gallagher, have been singled out
by Bridgers as the standouts of
an improving line. However, the
injury to Gallagher has left the
center corps thin and has caused
Bridgers to shift the versatile
McGraw to the pivot slot.
"If the switch of McGraw to
center is necessary, we probably
will open with Tom Ustach in
McGraw's tackle slot," stated the
Jay mentor earlier in the week.
Harding At Tail
At the moment the end corps,
led by Bill Civiletti, show the
most depth. Linemen Bill Widhelm and Don Macauley, drew
praise from Bridgers for their
work in last week's scrimmage.
At the focal point of the Blue
Jay's single wing attack is Cliff
Harding, the junior tailback from
Gilman. According to Bridgers,
Harding has improved his passing and punting to augment his
fine running to give the Jays an
all important triple threat tailback. Backing up Harding are
Ernie Bates, a fleet letterman,
and Guy Railey, who led the
Jay punters last year.

Altered Inner Gear Policy:
Cash Paid For Cards Now
Marshall Turner, Johns Hopkins University Athletic Director, has announced a new policy
which calls for the purchase of
an inner gear card for $3.50 at
the Treasurer's Office in Whitehead Hall.
This system differs from the
plan of former years when inner
gear cards were issued at the
beginning of the school year,
while the bill was paid in June.
Treasurer's Request
The new arrangement was initiated at the request of the Treasurer's Office, according to Turner,
because of a difficult and busy
work schedule in June.
"If a boy loses a card, he is
to notify Mr. Sachs. There will
be no penalty for an initial loss,
but a repeating violator may be
penalized," said Turrnr.

As in the past, all freshmen
participating in the physical
education course have been issued lockers.
Unused Lockers
An upperclassman who wishes
to use the gym facilities must
purchase a card at Whitehead
Hall. There are approximately
200 unused lockers in the gym.
An upperclassman may use a
locker and pla-..e his own lock
on the locker. However, the lock
cannot remain on the locker
overnight and the locker must
be emptied.
"The Physical Education Department reserves the right to
knock off any lock which is not
theirs if that lock is left on over
night," added the Athletic Director.

Practicing under the direction of Coach John Bridgers, the Jay forward wall is shown preparing to charge against a Franklin and Marshall defense, manned by fellow teammates. The
Jays have been practicing since early September on a two drills a day schedule. Injuries to
Don Gallagher and Sam -Wright have caused the Jay coach to experiment with Ken McGraw
at the center slot.
